abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second and the
            Third Poverty Reduction Support Credit/Grant (PRSC/G) for
            Rwanda are as follows: overall outcome was satisfactory,
            risk to the development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was rated highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) As evidenced by the allocation of expenditures
            under the Government of Rwanda (GoR's) budget over the
            period of the first PRSC/G series, the nominal amount
            allocated to the social sectors and agriculture increased
            due to the overall increase in public expenditure both in
            nominal and real terms, accompanied by an increase in GDP
            over the period. However, the share of the budget allocated
            to these sectors remained steady or decreased slightly (as
            in education). 2) The infrastructure sub sectors of water
            and energy were successfully supported as part of the
            service delivery agenda under the first PRSC/G series.
            Elevating the dialogue on these sub sectors allowed donor
            partners and GoR to address policy issues more efficiently
            and effectively than had been the case exclusively through
            projects. Sector priorities, support for local level private
            operator schemes in water, extra electricity generation
            capacity in energy, that were not being fully addressed
            through projects received support under the PRSC/G series.
            Inclusion in the PRSC/G series also forced these sub sectors
            to examine weaknesses in sector strategies, policy
            frameworks, Medium Term Economic Framework (MTEFs), and
            planning and budgeting, and established a foundation for, or
            accelerated, donor cooperation and the move to sector-wide
            approaches. 3) In large measure, members of the Bank team,
            including the task team leader and sector specialists,
            remained the same over the course of all three PRSC/Gs in
            the series. While this is unfortunately more often an
            exception rather than the rule, continuity in team
            leadership and team members was a contributing factor to the
            success of the program. GoR strongly highlighted the impact
            that team continuity had on the exceptionally robust
            dialogue between GoR and the PRSC/G team. Such continuity
            facilitated the building of strong relationships and trust
            and understanding amongst all parties and allowed for
            consistent follow-through on the agreed reform program. 4)
            While significant progress is evident within sectors, more
            work is needed to strengthen cross-sectoral linkages. The
            health and water sectors have taken steps to coordinate
            their efforts, but much more needs to be done to capture
            synergies between sectors.
